concept.title: Quick installation and setup
concept.shortdesc: You can install Couchbase Server on Linux, Microsoft Windows, or OS X systems. These streamlined instructions will help you get up and running right away in a nonproduction environment so you can start learning how to use Couchbase Server.

conbody.note: Use the quick installation and setup instructions on this page only to try out Couchbase Server. If you are installing Couchbase Server for development, test, or production purposes, set up Couchbase Server by following the detailed setup instructions in the Installation Guide.
You can also read about sizing the Couchbase Server cluster in the blog How many nodes?.

section.title: Downloading Couchbase Server
section.p: If you haven't already downloaded Couchbase Server, get it now from the Couchbase Server downloads page.
On a Linux system you can download Couchbase Server directly by using the wget command:
To find the URL to specify in the wget command, use your browser's tools such as Inspector for Chrome.

The following steps explain how to use Chrome's Inspector:
On the Coucbase Server's download page, right-click on the Download button next to the Linux version you want to download, such as SuSE Linux 11.
In the drop-down list select Inspect Element. The browser's Inspector screen opens on the right.
Select the highlighted area. The download URL for the selected Linux version will become available.

section.title: Installing on Red Hat or CentOS Linux systems
section.p: To install on Red Hat Enterprise Linux (RHEL) or CentOS Linux:

ol.li: Log on to the server as root.

Enter the following command to install Couchbase Server, replacing couchbase-server-version.rpm with the name of the file you downloaded:$ rpm --install couchbase-server-version.rpm
Couchbase Server starts automatically after the installation completes.

section.title: Installing on Debian or Ubuntu Linux systems
section.p: To install on Debian or Ubuntu Linux:

ol.li: Log on to the server as root.
Enter the following command to install OpenSSL, replacing version with a specific version number of OpenSSL:$ apt-get install libsslversion

Enter the following command to install Couchbase Server, replacing couchbase-server-version.deb with the name of the file you downloaded:$ dpkg -i couchbase-server-version.deb
Couchbase Server starts automatically after the installation completes.
Delete any previous installations of Couchbase Server either by using the command line or by dragging the Couchbase Server application to the Trash.
Open a Terminal window and delete any application support files from previous installations: $ rm -rf ~/Library/Application\ Support/Couchbase $ rm -rf ~/Library/Application\ Support/Membase

Expand the downloaded zip file (if it didn't expand automatically) and open the folder.
The folder contains the Couchbase Server application and a README.txt file.
Drag the Couchbase Server file to the Applications folder.

Start Couchbase Server by double-clicking the application icon.
If you get a message that says you can't run Couchbase Server due to security restrictions, right-click the icon for Couchbase Server and choose Open from the pop-up menu.
Double-click the downloaded executable file to start the installer.

Follow the installer prompts.
If desired, you can change the installation location.
If the default port is unavailable, the installer prompts you for a different port to use for server administration.
When the installer asks if you want to increase the number of ephemeral ports, click Yes.
After the installation is complete, restart Couchbase Server to apply the port changes.

section.title: Setting up Couchbase Server
section.p: Set up Couchbase Server when you start the Couchbase Web Console for the first time.
section.note: Use the quick installation and setup instructions on this page only to try out Couchbase Server. If you are installing Couchbase Server for development, test, or production purposes, set up Couchbase Server by following the detailed setup instructions in the Installation Guide.
section.p: To set up Couchbase Server in a nonproduction environment, you can accept the default values provided on most of the set-up screens.

ol.li:
Open a browser and navigate to http://hostname:8091/.
In the URL, hostname represents the name or IP address of the computer that hosts Couchbase Server. If Couchbase Server is running locally, you can use localhost for the host name.
Click Setup.
On the Configure Server (Step 1 of 5) screen, click Next to accept the default values.
On the Sample Buckets (Step 2 of 5) screen, click Next.
On the Create Default Bucket (Step 3 of 5) screen, under Memory Size set the Per Node RAM Quota to 100 MB and then click Next.
On the Notifications (Step 4 of 5) screen, enter your registration information, agree to the terms and conditions, and then click Next.

On the Configure Server (Step 5 of 5) screen, enter and verify a password for the administrator account, and then click Next.
The Couchbase Web Console opens and displays the Cluster Overview.

section.p: While the Couchbase Web Console is open, click on the tabs in the top menu and look at the screens to familiarize yourself with the information and available options.
